head.title: Why Napster Isn't the Bad Boy of Music

hedline.hl1: Why Napster Isn't the Bad Boy of Music

abstract.p: Paul F Brenner letter in defense of Napster suggests technology exists for allowing music lovers to hear music on Internet without downloading it for free (Oct 7 Op-Ed)

Re ''Songs That Won't Be Written,'' by Mike Stoller (Op-Ed, Oct. 7):
Mr. Stoller delivers a passionate case for protecting the songwriter's livelihood. But let's not throw out the baby with the bath water.
Napster is truly a technological and wonderful innovation. It has given access to music long forgotten. Who would deprive an aging baby boomer of the opportunity to resurrect his old favorites?
Why is it not possible to add to the technology that would stop users from downloading songs that are in the infancy of their creation, at a time when artists are due their just financial rewards?
I suspect that technology has the capacity to do this. But if not, Napster and other companies like it have the ability to wipe out user access of those who abuse this newest of technological gifts.
PAUL F. BRENNER Tinton Falls, N.J., Oct. 7, 2000
